G. L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 28, which authorizes the modification of prior custody judgments when there has been a material change in circumstances, and such modification is in the best interests of the child.

G. L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: The Middlesex Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G. L. c. 209C, § 10, as both parties and the minor child reside within the Commonwealth.

Partridge v. Partridge, 14 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Partridge v. Partridge, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 918 (1982)
Partridge v. Partridge, 14 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a modification of a custody or parenting order may be granted upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child.
Partridge v. Partridge, 14 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns division of property, alimony, child support, valuation of closely held stock, and the timeliness of an appeal. It does not discuss modification standards for custody or parenting orders, nor does it mention a requirement of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ or analyze the best interests of the child in the context of modifying a prior custody/parenting judgment. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Partridge v. Partridge, 14 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "The supplementary judgment entered on January 16, 1981, is vacated. The judge is to conduct a new trial on the questions of alimony, child support, and the division of property at which the parties are to be permitted the opportunity to present further evidence and to be heard thereon. At the conclusion of the trial, the judge is to make new determinations on the support issues in light of the present needs and circumstances of the parties..."

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: A child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in any custody determination.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court repeatedly states that the governing standard in both custody and removal decisions is the child’s best interests. In discussing the removal statute and the “real advantage” test, the opinion explicitly affirms that the best interests of the children “always remain the paramount concern,” directly aligning with the proposition that a child’s best interests are paramount in custody determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 613 (.raw_text: Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 613 (1987)
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 613 (.proposition: The court may consider the child’s expressed preferences, provided that the child possesses the maturity to articulate meaningful wishes.
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 613 (.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the evidentiary weight of a child’s stated custodial preference, noting that the child’s preference is a factor but not decisive, and cites a line of Massachusetts cases on considering a child’s wishes when the child is of sufficient age. While the opinion does not use the word “maturity,” it refers to the ten‑year‑old as “very bright, honest, and articulate,” and treats his expressed wishes as one factor among many in the best‑interests analysis. This aligns with the proposition that a court may consider a child’s expressed preferences where the child can articulate meaningful wishes.
Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 613 (.relevant_excerpt: “Tony’s custody presents a closer question. His father appears to have indoctrinated him with some dislike for his mother, and he has expressed a preference for Bielefeld. … The preference of someone Tony’s age (ten at the time of the proceedings) is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. … The judge could give consideration to the report of one of the court’s family service officers that Tony had not suffered any emotional damage… [and] found Tony to be ‘a very bright, honest, and articulate 9-year old’ ….”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819.proposition: The strong bond between a child and each parent is a factor to be weighed heavily in custody determinations.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses factors relevant to removal and custody-related determinations, emphasizing the best interests of the child, the welfare of the custodial parent, and the importance of preserving the relationship with the noncustodial parent. However, it does not state or clearly imply that a "strong bond between a child and each parent" is a factor to be weighed heavily; rather, it focuses on the custodial parent–child family unit and alternative visitation patterns. The proposition overstates and reframes the case’s reasoning about visitation and custodial well-being.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819.relevant_excerpt: From what we can ascertain, the judge recognized the importance of the " ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents," Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. at 234, quoting from Cal. Civ. Code § 4600 (West 1981 Supp.), and entered his judgment prohibiting removal on the basis that the move would make visitation more difficult. We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account.

Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).proposition: The support and recommendations of treating professionals, such as therapists, are highly relevant to serve a child’s best interests.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the procedural right to cross‑examine a guardian ad litem whose investigative report is relied on in a custody decision. While it notes that court‑appointed investigators can assist the judge in determining a child’s best interests, it does not specifically address or elevate the role of treating professionals’ (e.g., therapists’) recommendations. Thus, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about the particular relevance of treating professionals’ support or recommendations.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ … In order to provide the judge with needed information about a child’s family life, G. L. c. 215, § 56A… authorizes a probate judge to appoint a guardian ad litem to investigate the facts relating to the care and custody of the minor children….”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A material improvement in a parent’s living situation or ability to care for the child can warrant modification of a prior custody order.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/modification case under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and § 30. The Appeals Court explicitly holds that the mother’s remarriage after the divorce is a "material and substantial change in circumstances" and criticizes the trial judge for failing to treat it as such. While the opinion focuses on relocation rather than generic custody modification, it clearly recognizes that a significant change in the custodial parent’s circumstances (here, remarriage and associated living situation) can warrant revisiting the prior custody-related order, which is consistent with the proposition.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… "Upon a complaint after a divorce … the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred"… In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances…
